4T Sustainability Microrandomized Trial

Power simulations

Source: vignettes/microrandomization_setup.Rmd
microrandomization_setup.Rmd

Model

TIRij=β0+γi+β1Trtij+β2Timeij+β3TrtijTimej+eij, TIR_{ij} = \beta_0 + \gamma_i + \beta_1 Trt_{ij} + \beta_2 Time_{ij} + \beta_3 Trt_{ij} Time_j + e_{ij},

with

γi∼N(0,σγ2),eij∼N(0,σe2),γi⊥eij \gamma_i \sim N(0, \sigma_\gamma^2), \quad e_{ij} \sim N(0, \sigma_e^2), \quad \gamma_i \perp e_{ij}

Also, β1=0\beta_1 = 0 since, at baseline, the treatment effect is zero. The correlation between two TIRs for the same patient will be given by

ρ=Cor(TIRij,TIRij′)=(1+(σe/σγ)2)−1. \rho = Cor(TIR_{ij}, TIR_{ij'}) = (1 + (\sigma_e/\sigma_\gamma)^2)^{-1}.

In all simulated scenarios, we fixed σe/σγ=0.5\sigma_e/\sigma_\gamma = 0.5, such that ρ=0.8\rho = 0.8. Also, we assume a baseline TIR before microrandomization of β0=0.75\beta_0 = 0.75 and a baseline time trend of β2=−0.005\beta_2 = -0.005 as patients get progressively worse TIR if not intervened.

Thus, using sample sizes of 25, 50, 100, and 200, we simulate

TIRij=.75+γi−0.005Timeij+β3TrtijTimej+eij, TIR_{ij} = .75 + \gamma_i - 0.005 Time_{ij} + \beta_3 Trt_{ij} Time_j + e_{ij},

under the following scenarios

Scenarios A1-A5

  • β1=0.005,0.0025,0.001,0.0005,0.0001\beta_1 = 0.005, 0.0025, 0.001, 0.0005, 0.0001
  • σe=0.1\sigma_e = 0.1 and σγ=0.2\sigma_\gamma = 0.2

Scenarios B1-B5

  • β1=0.005,0.0025,0.001,0.0005,0.0001\beta_1 = 0.005, 0.0025, 0.001, 0.0005, 0.0001
  • σe=0.08\sigma_e = 0.08 and σγ=0.16\sigma_\gamma = 0.16

Scenarios C1-C2

  • β1=0\beta_1 = 0
  • C1: σe=0.1\sigma_e = 0.1 and σγ=0.2\sigma_\gamma = 0.2
  • C2: σe=0.08\sigma_e = 0.08 and σγ=0.16\sigma_\gamma = 0.16

@fig-rct has data from a non-microrandomized sample of size 100, i.e., patients simply randomized to default or add-on treatment at baseline.

data for a randomized (single randomization at baseline, not microrandomized) sample of 100 patients.

Simulation results

The results below were obtained using B=2000B = 2000 replications of the scenarios described above.

average number of participants at risk and add-on treatment provided over the study weeks
